intro: Tephroseris rufa var. rufa, commonly known as the red sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its compact, mat-forming growth habit. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers that are typically pink to red in color, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or sandy habitats. The species is noted for its drought tolerance and ability to stabilize soil in arid environments.
